title-group.article-title: Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort Heteroscyphus coalitus and their antivirulence activity against Candida albicans

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort
Heteroscyphus coalitus
and their antivirulence activity against
Candida albicans

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Xue Wang a , Xue-Yang Jin a , Jin-Chuan Zhou b , Rong-Xiu Zhu c , Ya-Nan Qiao a , Jiao-Zhen Zhang a ,

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Yi Li a , Chun-Yang Zhang a , Wang Chen d , Wen-Qiang Chang a , Hong-Xiang Lou
a,
∗

250012, China

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Liverwort
Terpenoids
Anti-virulence
A B S T R A C T

In this study, 14 previously undescribed terpenoids were isolated from the Chinese liverwort
Heteroscyphus coalitus (Hook.) Schiffner
, including a rare harziane type diterpenoid, heteroscyphsic acid A ; eight ent -clerodane diterpenoids, heteroscyphsic acids B–I; four labdane diterpenoids, heteroscyphins A –D; and one guaiane sesquiterpene, heteroscyphin E; as well as a known ent -junceic acid. Their structures were determined by a combination of MS, NMR spectroscopy, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) and single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The anti-virulence activity of the isolated compounds against
Candida albicans DSY
654 demonstrated that most of them could block hyphal growth at concentrations ranging from 4–32 μ g/ml. Further investigation of the most active compound, heteroscyphin D, revealed that it could suppress the ability of
C. albicans DSY
654 to adhere to A 549 cells and form biofilms , and modulate the transcription of related genes in this fungus.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2.1. Isolation and identi fi cation of previously undescribed compounds
sec.p:
Heteroscyphsic acid A ( 1 ) was obtained as colourless crystals. The HRESIMS data analysis resulted in this compound being assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 30 O 2 based on m/z 301.2170 [M − H] − (calcd 301.2173), suggesting six degrees of unsaturation. The IR absorption at 1681 cm −1 indicated the presence of a carbonyl group in 1 . Three methyl groups at δ H 0.62 (s), 0.97 (s), and 1.00 (d, J = 5.0 Hz) were identified from the 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ). The 13 C NMR ( Table 1 ) and HSQC data showed 20 carbons as two vinylic carbons ( δ C
110.5, 150.7), four quaternary carbons (including one carbonyl carbon at δ C
185.8), four methine groups, seven methylene groups and three methyl groups. Notably, two carbon resonances at δ C
22.4 [C-16 ( CH 3 ), C-7 ( CH 2 )] were overlapped. The carboxyl group was demonstrated to link to C-13 from the HMBC correlative signals of H-10 ( δ H 3.63), H 2 -12 ( δ H 2.05, 2.43), and H-14 ( δ H 2.59) to C-19 ( δ C
185.8) ( Fig. 2 ). The HMBC correlations from H 3 -16 ( δ H 0.97) and H 3 -17 ( δ H 0.62) to C-1 ( δ C
44.6), C-2 ( δ C
44.8), C-6 ( δ C
51.9), from H 3 -18 ( δ H 1.00) to C-4 ( δ C
25.5), C-5 ( δ C
37.2), C-6, as well as the linkage moiety CH (14)– CH 2 (15)– CH (2)– CH 2 (3)– CH 2 (4)– CH (5) from the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum ( Fig. 2 ) indicated a 6/5 dicarbocyclic substructure. The spin systems of CH 2 (7)– CH 2 (8), CH (10)– CH 2 (11)– CH 2 (12), and the key HMBC correlations from H-14 ( δ H 2.59) to C-13 ( δ C
54.8), C-12 ( δ C
32.3) and C-6, as well as from H-10 ( δ H 3.63) to C-8 ( δ C
33.5) and C-9 ( δ C
150.7) indicated the other 7/4 dicarbocyclic substructure. Taken together, this information indicated that 1 possessed a harziane tetracyclic diterpene skeleton (
), which was reported as a unique diterpene isolated from
Trichoderma species
(
). Thus, this was the first time that a harziane tetracyclic diterpene has been separated from plants, especially from liverworts. The NOE experimental results ( Fig. 3 ) showed correlations of both H-5 and H-12 α to H-14, suggesting that these protons were co-facial and regarded as
α -
oriented. The β orientation of H-10 was supported by the correlation from H-10 to H-12 β. The absolute configuration of 1 was assigned ( Fig. 1 ) on the basis of the Flack parameter [x = 0.0 (3)] (CCDC, 1,955,138) from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis with Cu K α radiation, and 1 was defined as (2 R ,5
S
,6
S
,10 R ,13
S
,14 R )-harzian-9 (20)-en-19-oic acid (see Fig. 4 ).

Heteroscyphsic acid B ( 2 ) was obtained as a white amorphous powder. The molecular formula C 20 H 28 O 4 ( m/z 355.1878 [M + Na] + , calcd 355.1880), with 7 degrees of unsaturation, was established based on the HRESIMS data. Two strong absorptions at 1748 and 1692 cm −1 from the IR spectrum showed the existence of two carbonyl groups in 2 . The 1 H NMR data ( Table 2 ) displayed three methyl groups at δ H 0.94 (s), 1.11 (d, J = 6.8 Hz) and 1.57 (s), one oxygenated methylene at δ H 4.78 (s), and two olefinic protons at δ H 5.23 (s) and 7.14 (s). Two pairs of vinylic carbons ( δ C
121.0, 143.3, 134.2, and 144.0), an ester carbonyl group ( δ C
174.2), and a carboxyl group ( δ C
182.3) were revealed by analyzing the 13 C NMR ( Table 5 ) and HSQC data. Combined with the other six methylenes and two methines, a clerodane skeleton of a diterpenoid was established (
). The correlation signals of H-14 ( δ H 7.14, s) to C-13 ( δ C
134.2), C-15 ( δ C
70.3), C-16 ( δ C
174.2) and C-12 ( δ C
18.7) along with H 2 -15 ( δ H 4.78) to C-13, C-14, and C-16 from the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 ) demonstrated the presence of a 15-methylene-but-13-en-16,15-olide moiety linked to C-12. The HMBC correlation between H-10 and C-20 ( δ C
182.3) proved that the carboxyl was at C-20. Four structural fragments CH (10)− CH 2 (1)− CH 2 (2)− CH (3), CH 2 (6)− CH 2 (7)− CH (8), CH 2 (11)− CH 2 (12), and CH (14)− CH 2 (15) were supported by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations ( Fig. 2 ). The NOESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ) from both H 3 -19 and H 3 -17 to H-7 β demonstrate that these protons were co-facial, and they were regarded as β -oriented. The
α -
orientations of H-10 and H-8 were determined by the NOE correlations from both H-10 and H-8 to H-6 α . The absolute configuration of 2 was identified by using ECD calculation, and the trend of experimental ECD data was roughly the same as that observed for the calculated one (Fig. S 141). Accordingly, compound 2 was confirmed as (5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10 R )-cleroda-3,13-dien-16,15-olide-20-oic acid.
Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.

Heteroscyphsic acid C ( 3 ) was assigned a molecular formula of C 20 H 28 O 5 ( m/z 371.1828 [M + Na] + , calcd 371.1829), with seven indices of hydrogen deficiency, based on the HRESIMS data. A comparison of the 1D NMR data ( Tables 2 and 4 ) with those of 2 showed the presence of the hydroxy group at C-15, which was further proved by the downfield shift of C-15 ( δ C
97.3) and the molecular formula ( Fig. 1 ). The NOE correlations from both H-10 and H-8 to H-6 α , from both H 3 -19 and H 3 -17 to H-7 β indicated the relative configuration of 3 was the same as that determined for 2 regarding the decalin moiety. By comparing the ECD data of 3 (Fig. S 30) with those of 2 , 3 was identified as (5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10 R )-15-hydroxycleroda-3,13-dien-16,15- olide-20-oic acid.

Heteroscyphsic acid D ( 4 ) was isolated as a pair of diastereomers and given the molecular formula C 21 H 30 O 5 ( m/z 380.2435 [M + NH 4 ] + calcd 380.2432) based on the HRESIMS data. The 1D NMR data ( Table 3 ) resembled those of 3 , except for the absence of the hydroxy group at C- 15 in 3 and the existence of a methoxy group in 4 . Slight variation in the chemical shifts at C-3, C-4, C-10, and –OMe and the NOE correlations of H-10/H-6 α , H-8/H-6 α , H 3 -19/H-7 β , and H 3 -17/ H-7 β demonstrated that 4 consisted of two C-15 epimers. The mixture 5 was also determined to be a pair of C-15 epimers, and the only difference between 4 and 5 was that the methoxy group in 4 was replaced by an ethoxy group in 5 . Therefore 5 was named as heteroscyphsic acid E. Here, the deduction of the absolute configuration of mixture 4 was used as an example. We adopted ECD calculation method to calculate these two epimers and mixed them at a 1:1 ratio to get the ECD spectrum of the mixture, which was compared with the experimental one (
), and the results were shown in Fig. 5 . HPLC analysis was used to support that 4 and 5 were produced by
H. coalitus
, not artefactual derivatives (Fig. S 142).

Heteroscyphsic acid F ( 6 ) was given the same molecular formula as 3 based on the NMR and HRESIMS data. The 1D NMR results ( Tables 2 and 5 ) exhibited similar chemical shifts to those presented in compound 3 . The typical downfield shift of C-13 ( δ C
169.7), as well as the upfield shift of C-14 ( δC 117.3), proved that there was a 16-hydroxy-but-13-en-15,16-olide moiety in 6 , thus differing in this respect from 2–5 . The differences in chemical shifts were relevant to the electron shielding effect of the conjugated carbonyl group on the β -carbon (
). The relative configuration of the decalin moiety was established by NOESY correlations from both H 3 -19 and H 3 -17 to H-7 β ; H-10 to H-11 α , and H-11 β , which were similar to those of 2−5 . By comparing the experimental ECD spectrum of 6 (Fig. S 60) with those of compounds 2–5 , the structure of 6 was defined as (5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10 R )-16-hydroxycleroda-3,13-dien-15,16-olide-20-oic acid.
Data of 2 , 7–9 were measured at 400 MHz, data of 3 and 6 were measured at 600 MHz.
a Recorded in CDCl.
3 b Recorded in CD OD. Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.

Heteroscyphsic acid G ( 7 ) was given the same molecular formula as compound 2 ( C 20 H 28 O 4 ) based on the HRESIMS data. By comparing the 1D NMR ( Tables 2 and 5 ) and HMBC correlations of 2 to those of 7 , the γ -lactone ring linked to C-12 was determined to be a 16-methylene-but-13-en-15,16-olide moiety in 7 . The NOESY spectrum and ECD data (Fig. S 70) revealed that the stereochemistry of 7 was the same as that of 2 , resulting in it being identified as (5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10 R )-cleroda-3,13-dien-15,16-olide-20-oic acid.

Heteroscyphsic acid H ( 8 ), which was assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 32 O 3 based on the HRESIMS data ([M + NH 4 ] + m/z 338.2695, calcd 338.2690) and 13 C NMR data, has two fewer indices of hydrogen deficiency than 2 . The 1D NMR spectra of 8 closely resembled those of 15-hydroxycleroda-3, (13 E )-dien-20-oic acid (
). The – C ( CH 3 )– CH – CH 2 OH moiety linked to C-12 was supported by the HMBC correlations from the H-16 ( δ H 1.70, s) to C-12 ( δ C
33.6), C-13 ( δ C
139.8), C-14 ( δ C
125.1). The NOE signal between H 2 -15 and H 3 -16 for 8 supported the presence of an E -double bond between C-13 and C-14, and the 1 H– 1 H correlations observed from the NOESY spectrum confirmed the relative configuration of 8 , which was the same as that of 2 . The observed experimental ECD spectrum (Fig. S 80) proved that 8 was a congener of 2 but an enantiomer of 15-hydroxycleroda-3, (13 E )-dien-20-oic acid. Ultimately, compound 8 was named as (13 E )- (5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10 R )-15-hydroxycleroda-3,13-dien-20-oic acid.

Heteroscyphsic acid I ( 9 ) was identified as an analogue of compound 8 according to 1D NMR data ( Tables 2 and 5 ). The HRESIMS data showed a [M + Na] + ion peak at m/z 385.2348 (calcd 385.2349), indicating that 9 has a molecular formula C 22 H 34 O 4 . The HMBC spectrum displayed a cross-peak caused by a methyl ( δ H 2.05, s) and a carbonyl ( δ C
171.2) groups, demonstrating the side chain linked to C-15 was a –OAc moiety. The E -double bond between C-13 and C-14 and the relative configuration of 9 were considered to be identical to that of the above compounds according to the NOE results, and their experimental ECD curves were extremely similar. Therefore, the structure of 9 was defined as (13 E )-(5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10 R )-15-acetoxy-cleroda-3,13-dien-20-oic acid.

Heteroscyphin A ( 10 ) was obtained as a colourless oil and was assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 28 O 3 from the HRESIMS data ( m/z 317.2116 [M + H] + , calculated for C 20 H 29 O 3 317.2111), containing seven indices of hydrogen deficiency. With the further analysis of the HMBC ( Figs. 2 ) and 1 H– 1 H COSY spectra ( Fig. 2 ), compound 10 was deduced to be a labdane diterpene that was closely related to a known labda-7,12 Z ,14-triene (
) except for the presence of a carbonyl group at C-6 ( δ C
205.6) and a carboxyl group at C-19 ( δ C
176.3), which was supported by the HMBC correlations from H-5 to C-6 and from both H 2 -3 and H 3 -18 to C-19, respectively. The molecular formula also proved the existence of the carboxyl group. NOE correlations ( Fig. 3 ) from H-5 to H 3 -18, H-1 α , and H-3 α , and from H-9 to H-1 α indicated that these protons were co-facial and α -oriented. The β -orientation of H 3 -20 was determined by the correlation between H 3 -20 and H-3 β . Moreover, the NOE experiments suggested that the sp 2 carbon (Δ 12 ) was E -configuration due to the correlations of H 3 -16 with trans- H-15b ( δ H 5.12, d, J = 17.3 Hz) and of H-12 with H-14 ( δ H 6.33, dd, J = 17.3, 10.7 Hz). Experimental and calculated ECD curves (Fig. S 141) were again used to confirm the absolute configuration of 10 , which was identified as (7 Z ,12 E )-(4
S
,5 R ,9
S
,10 R )-labda-7,12,14-trien-19-acid-6-one.

A molecular formula for C 20 H 30 O 2 with six indices of hydrogen deficiency and m/z at 303.2321 [M + H] + (calcd 303.2319) of heteroscyphin B ( 11 ) was confirmed by HRESIMS data. The peak at 3394 cm
− 1
in the IR spectrum was attributed to a hydroxy group. The 1D NMR ( Tables 4 and 5 ) data of 11 resembled that of compound 10 , except that the carboxyl group in 10 was reduced twice to become a – CH 2 OH moiety in 11 . This deduction was also supported by the HMBC correlations of H 2 -18 to C-3 ( δ C
39.9), C-4 ( δ C
37.7), C-5 ( δ C
64.8), and C-18 ( δ C
27.7). NOESY correlations illustrated that H-9, H-5, and H 3 -18 were positioned on the same plane, while H 2 -19 and H 3 -20 were on the other plane. The ECD spectrum of 11 (Fig. S 110) displayed parallel behaviour with that of compound 10 , and the absolute configuration was identified as (7 Z ,12 E )-(4
S
,5 R ,9
S
,10 R )-19-hydroxylabda-7,12,14- trien-6-one ( Fig. 1 ).
Data of 10–12 were recorded at 600 MHz in CDCl 3 , data of 13 were recorded at
400 MHz in CDCl 3 .
Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.
Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.

Heteroscyphin C ( 12 ) was determined to have the molecular formula C 20 H 30 O 3 based on the HRESIMS peak at m/z 319.2270 [M + H] + (calculated for C 20 H 31 O 3 319.2268), indicating it possessed one fewer indices of hydrogen deficiency than 10 . The 1D NMR data ( Tables 4 and 5 ) for compound 12 were highly similar to those of 10 , except that the double bond between C-7 ( δ C
59.0) and C-8 ( δ C
76.9) was hydrated and the aldehyde carbonyl group at C-19 ( δ C
206.9), which were supported by the HMBC correlations from H 2 -7 ( δ H 2.56, 2.77) to C-6, C-8, C-9 and C-17, as well as from H 2 -3 ( δ H 0.88, 2.17), H-5 ( δ H 2.64) and H 3 -18 ( δ H 1.11) to C-19, respectively. Similar to 10 , the lateral chain linked to C-12 was identified as an E -double bond from the 2D NOESY spectrum. Combined with the ECD calculation of 12 (Fig. S 141), the opposite cotton effect of 12 compared to the ECD spectrum of 10 indicated that the stereochemistry of 12 was distinct from 10 . Namely, 12 was identified as (7 Z ,12 E )-(4 R ,5
S
,8
S
,9
S
,10
S
)-8-hydroxy-19-oxo- ent -labda-12,14-dien-6-one.

Heteroscyphin D ( 13 ) has a molecular formula C 20 H 30 O 3 with six degrees of unsaturation, as established by the 13 C NMR and HRESIMS data ( m/z 341.2090 [M + Na] + , calcd 341.2087). Compound 13 was identified as an analogue of 12 according to the 1D NMR data ( Tables 4 and 5 ). Furthermore, the existence of germinal methyl groups attached to C-4 was identified by HMBC correlations from H 3 -18 ( δ H 1.17) to C-19 ( δ C
33.7), C-3 ( δ C
41.6), C-4 ( δ C
33.3), and C-5 ( δ C
46.5). In addition, the HMBC cross-peaks between H-11 ( δ H 5.09) and C-20 ( δ C
178.0), H-1 ( δ H 1.41, 2.18) and C-20, as well as H-5 ( δ H 1.90) and C-20 proved that there was a lactone ring comprising C-9, C-10, C-11, and C-20. The β - orientations of H-9, H-11, and H 3 -17 were identified by the NOE correlations of H 3 -17/H-9, H 3 -17/H-11. Accordingly, the α -orientation of C-20 and the stereochemistry as an ent -labdane of 13 were determined with the aid of the ECD calculation (Fig. S 141).

Heteroscyphin E ( 14 ) has a molecular formula C 15 H 22 O 2 , according to the HRESIMS ( m/z 235.1694 [M + H] + , calcd 235.1693) and 13 C NMR ( Table 6 ) data. The 1D NMR spectra ( Table 6 ) of compound 14 closely resembled those of α -gurjunene (
) except for the C-2 resonance, which indicated that a carbonyl group ( δ C
208.8) replaced the methylene group in the known α -gurjunene. The HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from H-1 and H-3 to C-2 confirmed the location of the carbonyl group at C-2. In addition, the NOE correlation ( Fig. 3 ) of H-1/H-10 illustrated that these protons were on the same plane, while the cross-peaks between H 3 -14 and H-9 β , H-7 and H-9 β suggested that these protons were on the other plane. To prove these results, ECD calculation was performed, and the results matched the experimental ECD spectrum perfectly (Fig. S 141). Ultimately, compound 14 was named as (1
S
,7
S
,10
S
)-11-hydroxyguaia-3,5-dine-2-one.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Data of 2 , 9 , 13 were measured at 100 MHz, data of 3 , 6–8 , 10–12 were measured at 150 MHz.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Recorded in CDCl.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 3 b Recorded in CD OD. Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 2.2. Terpenoids inhibited the yeast-to-hyphal transition of C. albicans

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Since hypha have long been considered to be a major factor affecting fungal virulence, we investigated the effect of all undescribed compounds on the hyphal growth of the
C. albicans
wild-type strain SC5314 and the efflux pump deficient strain DSY 654 in vitro by microphotography, with fluconazole (FLC) used as a positive control (
) ( Table S1 ). Compound 13 could restrict the formation of hyphae by
C. albicans DSY
654 within 6 h at the low concentration of 4 μ g/ml ( Fig. 6A ) but showed no activity against SC5314. Thus, compound 13 was selected for further investigation of its inhibitory effect toward virulence factors. Furthermore, the minimum inhibitory concentrations of undescribed compounds with an 80% reduction (MIC 80 ) were also evaluated ( Table S2 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
2.3. Inhibitory e ff
ect of compound 13 on the adhesion of C. albicans DSY654 to A549 cells

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Because adhesion is the first step in fungal infections, we examined the ability of compound 13 to inhibit the adhesion of
C. albicans DSY
654 to the surface of A549 cells, and the fluorescent strains were adopted to make the results clearer. As shown in Fig. 6B and C , 13 decreased the quantity of adherent
C. albicans
cells on A549 cancer cell monolayers in a dose-dependent manner, indicating that 13 could suppress the adhesion of
C. albicans DSY
654 to biological substrates.

sec.title:
2.4. Compound 13 suppressed the bio fi
lm formation of C. albicans DSY 654
sec.p:
During the process of
C. albicans
infection, biofilm formation has been increasingly recognized as a key virulence factor that influenced the rate of death (
). The ability of
C. albicans
to form biofilms was assessed using an XTT reduction assay, and the results suggested that the biofilm structure was greatly destroyed at 4 μ g/ml of compound 13 , while biofilm formation was completely prevented with as dose increased to 8 μ g/ml or higher ( Fig. 6D and E ).

sec.title: 2.5. qPCR results
sec.p:
To uncover the underlying molecular basis for the inhibited hyphal growth and cell adhesion caused by compound 13 , a qPCR analysis was performed to assess the transcription levels of genes associated with hyphal growth and cell adhesion in
C. albicans
when treated with compound 13 . The mRNA levels of selected genes were examined, namely,
RAS 1
, CDC35 , PDE2 , EFG1 , CST20 , HST7 , CEK1 , BCR1 , TEC1 , NRG1 , UME6 , ALS3 , HWP1 , and ECE1 . As indicated in Fig. 6F , the transcriptional levels of three genes encoding adhesins, namely, ALS3 , HWP1 , and ECE1 , were decreased after 6 h in cells treated with 13 . Furthermore, the expression of genes associated with the Ras 1-cAMP-Efg1 pathway was altered to varying extents. PDE2 , encoding phosphodiesterase, was upregulated in the presence of 13 , which suggested a decrease in the intracellular cAMP content, and this abnormal change in the cAMP level would block this pathway, and impair the virulence consequently. In addition, the expression of two important transcriptional factors, Nrg1 and Ume6, was observed to dramatically change when cells were treated with 13 . Several lines of evidence have confirmed that the expression of most hyphal-specific genes depended on UME6 expression, and Nrg1p and Ume6p act in a negative feedback loop to control gene expression during hyphal elongation. Thus, the upregulation of NRG1 and the downregulation of UME6 both contribute to the inhibition of mycelial growth. These results suggest that compound 13 affected the Ras 1-cAMP-Efg1 pathway, NRG1 and UME6 to retard the yeast-to-hyphae transition.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, fourteen previously undescribed compounds were isolated from
H. coalitus
, including a rare harziane diterpene, eight ent - clerodane-type diterpenoid acids, four labdane diterpenoids, and one guaiane sesquiterpene, as well as one known ent -clerodane diterpenoid. Clerodane diterpenoids and guaiane sesquiterpenoids are common terpenoids of
H. coalitus
according to the references (
,
;
;
), but the harziane and labdane diterpenoids are isolated from this species for the first time. Compounds 1–14 were evaluated for anti-virulence activities against
C. albicans SC
5314 and DSY 654, and nine compounds exhibited anti-filamentous activity against
C. albicans DSY
654 to various degrees but were ineffective against SC 5314. The different sensitivities of these nine compounds to the two strains resulted from their inability to be intracellularly retained in the wild-type strain due to their efflux by efflux pumps. Further investigations of heteroscyphin D ( 13 ) demonstrated that it possessed superior ability to inhibit the hyphal and biofilm formation of
C. albicans DSY
654. In addition, the adhesion ability of
C. albicans DSY
654 toward biological substrates was also restrained by heteroscyphin D ( 13 ), suggesting its potential antifungal activity in vivo. Many natural products have been reported to display activity against
C. albicans
from previous studies (
;
;
), and the inhibition of virulence factors could reduce the ability of
C. albicans
to cause infection. Thus, the identification of terpenoids with potential anti-virulence activity could enrich the drug library for developing novel leads against
C. albicans
infection.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations were acquired on an Anton Paar MCP 200 polarimeter at 20 ̊ C . HRESIMS data ( 2–10 , 12–14 ) were obtained using a Finnigan LC-QDECA mass spectrometer. HRESIMS data for compounds 1 and 11 were obtained using an Agilent Q-TOF LC/MS 6520 instrument. IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolet iN 10 Micro FTIR spectrometer. UV data were recorded using a Shimadzu UV-2450 spectrophotometer. ECD spectra were obtained on a Chirascan spectropolarimeter. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance DRX-600 spectrometer ( 1 H: 600 MHz, 13 C : 150 MHz) and a Bruker Avance AVIII-400 spectrometer ( 1 H: 400 MHz, 13 C : 100 MHz), using TMS as an internal standard. HPLC was performed on a Shimadzu LC-20AT pump equipped with a DGU-20 A 5R degasser, an SPD-M20 A detector, and a Shim-pack GIST-C 18 5 μ m column (10 × 250 mm ). MCI gel (CHP20P, 75–150 μ m, Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd.), silica gel (200–300 mesh; Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd.), Sephadex LH-20 (25–100 μ m; Pharmacia), and reversed-phase C 18 silica gel (150–200 mesh, Merck) were used for column chromatography. Precoated silica gel GF-254 glass plates (Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd., Qingdao, China ) were used for TLC. The compounds were visualized under UV ( 254 nm ) light and by spraying with H 2 SO 4 –EtOH (1:9, v/v) followed by heating.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
Whole
Heteroscyphus coalitus (Hook.) Schiffner (Geocalycaceae)
plants were collected from the Wuyan Ling National Nature Reserve (119̊37′08”~119̊50′00″E, 27̊20′52”~27̊48′39″N), Zhejiang Province , China , on May 18th, 2018 (wet season), and identified by Dr. Jinchuan Zhou (School of Pharmacy, Linyi University). A voucher specimen (No. 20180518025) has been deposited at the Department of Natural Products Chemistry, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Shandong University, China .

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
The air-dried and milled plant materials of
H. coalitus
( 787 g ) were extracted with 95% EtOH (3 × 1.5 L, each for one week) at room temperature, after which the mixture was filtered. The filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure at 40 ̊ C to afford the crude extract ( 23 g ), which was separated by MCI gel column chromatography (MeOH–H 2 O, 3:7 to 9:1) and yielded fractions 1–5. Fraction 2 ( 3.7 g ) was chromatographed using a silica gel column [petroleum ether (60–90 ̊ C )-acetone, 200:1 to 0:1] to yield subfractions 2A− 2M. Subfraction 2 F ( 130.57 mg ) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) and a RP-C 18 silica gel column (MeOH/H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) and then was purified by HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 77:23, 3 ml/min) to afford 2 ( 10.2 mg , t R = 22.5 min) and 4 ( 8.9 mg , t R = 28.3 min). Subfraction 2E ( 160.2 mg ) was further separated using a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH), and RP-C 18 silica gel column (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) to obtain subfractions E1 to E6, and subfraction E3 ( 45.5 mg ) was purified using HPLC [MeOH: CH 3 CN (3:1)-H 2 O, 78:22, 1.5 ml/min] to yield 5 ( 5.1 mg , t R = 53.5 min). Subfraction E1 ( 38.1 mg ) was further separated using a RP-C 18 silica gel column (MeOH–H 2 O, 3:7 to 5:5 and 10:0), and was purified by HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O, 40:60, 2 ml/min) to yield 14 ( 0.69 mg , t R = 23.5 min). Subfraction 2G ( 458.2 mg ) was further separated using a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) followed by a RP-C 18 silica gel column (MeOH–H 2 O, 4:6 to 10:0) to afford subfractions G1 to G7. Subfraction G4 ( 192.9 mg ) was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 76:24, 2.5 ml/min) to yield 8 ( 3.12 mg , t R = 50.5 min). Subfraction G3 ( 84.1 mg ) was separated with a RP-C 18 silica gel column again, and subfraction G3-3 (12.0 mg) was then purified by HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 77:23, 1.5 ml/min) to afford 7 ( 4.9 mg , t R = 33.0 min). Subfraction 2H ( 431.9 mg ) was successively applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) and a RP-C 18 silica gel column (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) to obtain an appropriate subfraction for purification by HPLC ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O, 60:40, 2 ml/min) to yield 3 ( 37.6 mg , t R = 19.0 min) and 6 ( 21.1 mg , t R = 21.5 min). Subfraction 2D ( 322.7 mg ) was further separated using a Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) and a RP-C 18 silica gel column (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0), followed by purification by HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 79:21, 1.5 ml/min) to obtain 10 ( 2.73 mg , t R = 42.5 min), 11 ( 1.42 mg , t R = 48 min), 12 ( 2.3 mg , t R = 31.0 min), as well as a mixture, the latter of which was repurified by HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 70:30, 2.5 ml/min) to yield 13 ( 2.08 mg , t R = 53.0 min). Fraction 4 ( 1.9 g ) was chromatographed using a silica gel column [petroleum ether (60–90 ̊ C )-acetone, 200:1 to 0:1] to yield subfractions 4A− 4L. Subfraction 4E ( 59.6 mg ) was separated on Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) and was purified by HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 85:15, 2.5 ml/ min) to afford 9 ( 11.1 mg , t R = 43.0 min). Subfraction 4 A ( 397.5 mg ) was further separated on a Sephadex LH-20 column, followed by an RPC 18 silica gel column (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) and then was purified by HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 87:13, 2.2 ml/min) to yield 1 ( 6.4 mg , t R = 40.0 min) and 15 ( 3.01 mg , t R = 33.0 min).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Heteroscyphsic acid A (1)
sec.p: Colorless crystals (MeOH); mp> 250 ̊ C ; [ α ] D 25 +25 (c 0.15 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 200 (Δ ε 5.03) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.42) nm; IR Ν max 3077, 3032, 2932, 2886, 1681, 1639, 1454, 1414, 1376, 1288, 1255, 1223, 837 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 301.2170 [M − H] − (calcd for C 20 H 29 O 2 , 301.2173).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Heteroscyphsic acid B (2)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +64 (c 0.35 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 225 (Δ ε −0.68) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.78) nm; IR Ν max 2958, 2874, 1748, 1450, 1343, 1206, 1071, 830 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 355.1878 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 28 NaO 4 , 355.1880).

sec.title: 4.3.3. Heteroscyphsic acid C (3)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +63 (c 0.10 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 226 (Δ ε −0.68) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.75) nm; IR Ν max 3272, 2957, 2884, 1737, 1694, 1453, 1258, 1178, 1131, 951 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 371.1828 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 28 NaO 5 , 371.1829).

sec.title: 4.3.4. Heteroscyphsic acid D (4)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +64 (c 0.50 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 226 (Δ ε −0.74) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.76), 256 (2.47), 273 (2.50) nm; IR Ν max 2958, 2935, 2872, 1770, 1693, 1451, 1368, 1206, 1025, 936 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz), see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 380.2435 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 21 H 34 NO 5 , 380.2432).

sec.title: 4.3.5. Heteroscyphsic acid E (5)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +48 (c 0.25 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 226 (Δ ε −0.60) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.74) nm; IR Ν max 2962, 2930, 2869, 1768, 1694, 1453, 1342, 1200, 1017, 937 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz), see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 377.2322 [M + H] + (calcd for C 22 H 33 O 5 , 377.2323).

sec.title: 4.3.6. Heteroscyphsic acid F (6)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +69 (c 0.05 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 228 (Δ ε −1.41) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.91) nm; IR Ν max 3316, 2958, 2880, 1747, 1693, 1439, 1252, 1201, 1007, 922 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 366.2276 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 32 NO 5 , 366.2275).

sec.title: 4.3.7. Heteroscyphsic acid G (7)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +48 (c 0.07 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 228 (Δ ε −0.68) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.73) nm; IR Ν max 3363, 2953, 2926, 2866, 1778, 1739, 1691, 1634, 1439, 1173, 1131, 1025, 854 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 350.2332 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 32 NO 4 , 350.2336).

sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +38 (c 0.02 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 224 (Δ ε −0.38) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.43) nm; IR Ν max 3306, 2957, 2923, 2875, 1691, 1438, 1380, 1252, 1234, 1192, 991 cm −1 ; 1 H (MeOD, 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (MeOD, 150 MHz), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 338.2695 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 36 NO 3 , 338.2690).

sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 25 +33 (c 0.07 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 227 (Δ ε −0.59) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.82) nm; IR Ν max 2958, 2878, 1737, 1694, 1440, 1370, 1234, 1025, 952 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz), see Tables 2 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 385.2348 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 22 H 34 NaO 4 , 385.2349).

sec.title: 4.3.10. Heteroscyphin A (10)
sec.p: Colorless oil; [ α ] D 25 +3.0 (c 0.10 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 204 (Δ ε 1.09) nm, 220 (Δ ε 0.39) nm, 242 (Δ ε 1.13) nm, 313 (Δ ε −0.25) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.61) nm; IR Ν max 3422, 2934, 2872, 1739, 1667, 1630, 1458, 1381, 1178, 988 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Tables 4 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 317.2116 [M + H] + (calcd for C 20 H 29 O 3 , 317.2111).

sec.title: 4.3.11. Heteroscyphin B (11)
sec.p: Colorless oil; [ α ] D 25 +16 (c 0.08 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 215 (Δ ε 1.01), 224 (Δ ε 0.90), 235 (Δ ε 1.13), 328 (Δ ε −0.11) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.42) nm; IR Ν max 3394, 2931, 2870, 1677, 1459, 1440, 1380, 1246, 1022, 986 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Tables 4 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 303.2320 [M + H] + (calcd for C 20 H 31 O 2 , 303.2319).

sec.title: 4.3.12. Heteroscyphin C (12)
sec.p: Colorless oil; [ α ] D 25 −44 (c 0.03 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 222 (Δ ε 0.036) nm, 244 (Δ ε −0.22), 312 (Δ ε 0.07) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.85) nm; IR Ν max 3410, 2933, 2878, 1710, 1454, 1378, 1235, 1157, 1038, 990 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 150 MHz), see Tables 4 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 319.2270 [M + H] + (calcd for C 20 H 31 O 3 , 319.2268).

sec.title: 4.3.13. Heteroscyphin D (13)
sec.p: Colorless oil; [ α ] D 25 −45 (c 0.05 MeOH); ECD (MeOH) 213 (Δ ε −1.39) nm, 312 (Δ ε 0.07) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.85) nm; IR Ν max 3410, 2933, 2878, 1710, 1454, 1378, 1235, 1157, 1038, 990 cm −1 ; 1 H (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz), see Tables 4 and 5 ; HRESIMS m/z 341.2090 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 30 NaO 3 , 341.2087).

sec.title: 4.4. X-ray crystallographic analysis of compound 1
sec.p: One suitable crystal of compound 1 was obtained by recrystallization in MeOH system and performed on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer. During the data collection process, the crystal was maintained at a temperature of 290 (2) K. Using ShelXL-2014/7, the structure was solved with the ShelXS structure solution program using Direct Methods and refined with the ShelXL-2014/7 refinement package using least squares minimization.

C 20 H 30 O 2 , M = 302.19 g /mol, monoclinic, space group P 21, a = 15.0053 (13) Å , b = 13.6367 (11) Å , c = 18.2094 (15) Å , β = 111.284 (5)̊, V = 3471.9 (5) Å 3 , Z = 8,
Dcalcd
= 1.156 g /cm 3 , μ (Cu K α ) = 1.542 mm −1 , F (000) = 1326, 9594 reflections measured (2.604̊ ≤ 2θ ≤ 66.594̊), 11,405 unique which were used in all calculations. The final stage converged to R 1 = 0.1211 ( wR 2 = 0.3374) for 6448 observed reflections [with I > 2 σ ( I )] and 805 variable parameters, and R 1 = 0.1790 ( wR 2 = 0.3842) for all unique reflections and GOF = 1.064. The flack parameter was 0.0 (3). Details of crystallographic data for 1 have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number CCDC 1955138. The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc. cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.
4.5. Strain and cell culture
4.6. Hyphal formation of C. albicans assay

The hyphal development ability was performed using a modified broth microdilution method (Wenqiang
). A
C. albicans DSY
654 cell suspension was prepared (at 10 5 cells/ml) in RPMI 1640 supplemented with a series of concentrations from 1 to 8 μ g/ml of the compound 13 and incubated at 37 ̊C without shaking. The morphology of
C. albicans DSY
654 cells was observed directly by the Olympus fluorescence microscope (Olympus IX71, Olympus, Tokyo , Japan ) at 6 h.
4.7. Cell adhesion assay

Quantification of
C. albicans
adherence to A 549 cells was performed as described previously (
). A 549 cells (2 × 10 4 cells/ well) were grown on 96 well plates in RPMI 1640 + 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and penicillin/streptomycin at 37 ̊ C for 24 h in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO 2 . The supernatants were decanted, and the plates were carefully washed three times with PBS to remove unbound cells. Then, 500- μ l of
C. albicans DSY
654 cell suspensions (1 × 10 6 cells/ml) mixed with different concentrations of 13 were plated into each well. After incubation at 37 ̊ C for 90 min, the medium was decanted, and the monolayers were washed carefully thrice with 500 μ l of PBS . Each well was photographed by an Olympus fluorescence microscope. The number of adherent
C. albicans DSY
654 cells was determined by counting the cells in the picture.

4.8. C. albicans bio
fi lm formation assay

The effect of compound 13 on biofilm formation was tested in 96- well microtiter plates using an XTT reduction assay followed the method previously reported (
). In this study, the cell suspension was prepared in RPMI 1640 medium at a cell density of 1 × 10 6 cells/ml with final concentrations of 0, 2, 4, 8, and 16 μ g/ml of 13 . A concentration of 2 μ g/ml of fluconazole (FLC) served as the positive control.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
4.9. Transcriptional levels of hyphal-speci fi
c genes in C. albicans

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Quantitative real-time PCR was adopted to investigate transcriptional levels of hyphal-relative genes under treatment of compound 13 (
).
C. albicans DSY
654 (1 × 10 5 cells/ml) cells were prepared in RPMI 1640 medium and challenged with 4 μ g/ml of 13 at 37 ̊C, 200 rpm for 6 h. At the end of incubation, cells were collected and washed two times with PBS. Total RNA was extracted using a hot phenol/chloroform protocol, and cDNA was synthesized using a cDNA synthesis kit (TaKaRa Biotechnology, Dalian, China ). PCR reactions were performed with an SYBR Green master mix (TaKaRa Biotechnology, Dalian, China ) in an Eppendorf Mastercycler Real-Time PCR System. Primer sequences used for amplification of specific genes were listed in Table S3 . The ratio of each mRNA relative to the 18 S rRNA was calculated using the 2 −ΔΔCT method; the results are represented as the mean ± SD.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112324.
